OpenAI investigation.title: Removal of Sam Altman from OpenAI - Wikipedia
OpenAI investigation.content:
In February 2024, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission was reportedly investigating OpenAI over whether internal company communications made by Altman were used to mislead investors, while an investigation of Altman's statements that was opened by the Southern New York U.S. Attorney's Office opened the previous November was ongoing.(

Reactions
---------

[edit]

### Sam Altman

[edit] [...] Multiple OpenAI investors are considering legal action.( On December 8, the Competition and Markets Authority announced it was beginning a preliminary investigation into Microsoft's relationship with OpenAI and its non-voting board observership.( Hours later, Bloomberg News reported that the Federal Trade Commission was separately examining the relationship.( In response, Microsoft stated that it does not hold a stake in OpenAI.( [...] 92.   ^Bass, Dina; Nylen, Leah (December 8, 2023). "Microsoft's Answer to OpenAI Inquiry: It Doesn't Own a Stake". Bloomberg News. Archived from the original on December 8, 2023. Retrieved December 8, 2023.
93.   ^Seetharaman, Deepa (February 28, 2024). "SEC Investigating Whether OpenAI Investors Were Misled". _The Wall Street Journal_. News Corp. Retrieved February 29, 2024.

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

2023 business action

[![Image 4](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6c/Wiki_letter_w.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w.svg)This article's [lead section](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Lead_section#Length "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Lead section")**may be too short to adequately [summarize](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Summary_style "Wikipedia:Summary style") the key points**. Please consider expanding the lead to [provide an accessible overview](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Lead_section#Provide_an_accessible_overview "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Lead section") of all important aspects of the article._(March 2024)_
[![Image 5](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Sam_Altman_TechCrunch_SF_2019_Day_2_Oct_3_%28cropped%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-Sam_Altman_TechCrunch_SF_2019_Day_2_Oct_3_%28cropped%29_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Sam_Altman_TechCrunch_SF_2019_Day_2_Oct_3_(cropped)_(cropped).jpg)

Altman, pictured in 2019

On November 17, 2023, [OpenAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI "OpenAI")'s [board of directors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Board_of_OpenAI "Board of OpenAI") ousted co-founder and chief executive [Sam Altman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Altman "Sam Altman") after the board had no confidence in his leadership. The removal was caused by concerns about his handling of [artificial intelligence safety](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_safety "Artificial intelligence safety"),[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-Anna_Tong_2023_u135-1)[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-TweakTown_2023_a134-2) and allegations of abusive behavior.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-WaPoReport-3) Altman was reinstated on November 22 after pressure from employees and investors.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-Efrati-4)

Background
----------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Background")]

### OpenAI

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: OpenAI")]

Main article: [OpenAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI "OpenAI")

[OpenAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI "OpenAI") is an artificial intelligence firm founded in December 2015 as a non-profit entity.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-SlateInfo-5) The for-profit division of the organization released the chatbot [ChatGPT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatGPT "ChatGPT") in November 2022,[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-EngadgetInfo-6) contributing to a resurgence in generative artificial intelligence funding.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-7) The board of directors of the controlling non-profit formerly comprised chief scientist [Ilya Sutskever](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ilya_Sutskever "Ilya Sutskever"), as well as [Adam D'Angelo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adam_D%27Angelo "Adam D'Angelo"), chief executive of [Quora](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quora "Quora"), entrepreneur Tasha McCauley, and [Helen Toner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helen_Toner "Helen Toner"), strategy director for the [Center for Security and Emerging Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Center_for_Security_and_Emerging_Technology "Center for Security and Emerging Technology").[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-8) As of October 2023, the company is valued at US$80 billion[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-9) and was set to bring in US$1 billion in revenue.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-10) Altman has described OpenAI's relationship with Microsoft as the "best [bromance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bromance "Bromance") in tech".[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-11)

OpenAI is uniquely[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-NYTimesRoose-12) structured, an intentional decision to avoid investor control.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-13) A board of directors controls the non-profit OpenAI, Inc. The non-profit owns and controls a for-profit company itself controlling a capped-profit company, OpenAI Global, LLC and a holding company owned by employees and other investors. The holding company is the majority owner of OpenAI Global, LLC.; Microsoft owns a minority stake in the capped-profit company.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-14) OpenAI's bylaws, enacted in January 2016, allow a majority of its board of directors to remove any director without prior warning or a formal meeting with written consent.[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-WiredBackground-15)

### Sam Altman

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Sam Altman")]

Main article: [Sam Altman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Altman "Sam Altman")

Sam Altman is a co-founder of OpenAI and its former chief executive; Altman took over the company following co-chair [Elon Musk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elon_Musk "Elon Musk")'s resignation in 2018. Under Altman, OpenAI has shifted to becoming a for-profit entity.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-SlateInfo-5) Altman is credited with convincing [Microsoft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft") chief executive [Satya Nadella](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satya_Nadella "Satya Nadella") with investing US$10 billion in cash and computing credits into OpenAI and leading several [tender offer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tender_offer "Tender offer") transactions that tripled the company's valuation.[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-16) Altman testified before the [United States Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") speaking critically of artificial intelligence[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-17) and appeared at the [2023 AI Safety Summit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_AI_Safety_Summit "2023 AI Safety Summit").[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-18)

In the days leading up to his removal, Altman made several public appearances, announcing the [GPT-4](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GPT-4 "GPT-4") Turbo platform at OpenAI's DevDay conference, attending [APEC United States 2023](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/APEC_United_States_2023 "APEC United States 2023"),[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-EngadgetInfo-6) and speaking at an event related to [Burning Man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burning_Man "Burning Man").[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-19)

Events leading up to the removal
--------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Events leading up to the removal")]

The resignation of [LinkedIn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LinkedIn "LinkedIn") co-founder [Reid Hoffman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reid_Hoffman "Reid Hoffman"), venture capitalist [Shivon Zilis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shivon_Zilis "Shivon Zilis"), and former Republican representative [Will Hurd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Will_Hurd "Will Hurd") from the board allowed the remaining members to remove Altman.[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-WiredBackground-15) According to [Kara Swisher](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kara_Swisher "Kara Swisher") and _[The Wall Street Journal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Wall\_Street\_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")_,[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-20) Sutskever was instrumental in Altman's removal.[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-21) Disagreements over the safety of artificial intelligence divided employees prior to Altman's removal.[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-22) The release of ChatGPT created divisions with OpenAI as a for-profit company without considerations for the safety of artificial intelligence and a non-profit cautious of artificial intelligence's capabilities; in a staff email sent in 2019 and obtained by _[The Atlantic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Atlantic "The Atlantic")_, Altman referred to these divisions as "tribes".[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-23)

Prior to his removal, Altman was seeking billions from Middle Eastern sovereign wealth funds to develop an artificial intelligence chip to compete with [Nvidia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nvidia "Nvidia") and courted [SoftBank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SoftBank "SoftBank") chairman [Masayoshi Son](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masayoshi_Son "Masayoshi Son") to develop artificial intelligence hardware with former [Apple](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple,_Inc. "Apple, Inc.") designer [Jony Ive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jony_Ive "Jony Ive"). Sutskever and his allies opposed these efforts, viewing them as unjustly using the OpenAI name. Altman reduced Sutskever's role in October 2023, furthering divisions; Sutskever successfully appealed to several members of the board.[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-BloombergCoup-24) Swisher and _[The Verge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Verge "The Verge")_ reporter Alex Heath stated that opposition to Altman's profit-driven strategy culminated in the DevDay conference[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-25) in which Altman announced custom ChatGPT instances.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-26) According to _[Axios](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axios\_(website) "Axios (website)")_, the removal was driven by growing discontent and distrust with Altman.[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-AxiosBackground-27)

On November 22, 2023, reports emerged suggesting that Sam Altman's dismissal from OpenAI might be linked to his alleged mishandling of a significant breakthrough in the organization's secretive project codenamed [Q*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q* "Q*"). According to sources within OpenAI, Q* is aimed at developing AI capabilities in logical and mathematical reasoning, and reportedly involves performing math on the level of grade-school students.[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-gradeschool-28) Concerns about Altman's response to this development, specifically regarding the potential safety implications of the discovery, were reportedly raised to the company's board shortly before his firing.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-Anna_Tong_2023_u135-1)[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-TweakTown_2023_a134-2)

A report from _[The Washington Post](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Washington\_Post "The Washington Post")_ in December stated that OpenAI's board of directors were concerned over Altman's allegedly abusive behavior; the complaints were purportedly a major factor in his removal.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-WaPoReport-3) The _Post_ previously reported that Altman's alleged pattern of deception and subversiveness that ostensibly resulted in his removal from [Y Combinator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Y_Combinator "Y Combinator") ultimately resulted in the board's decision to remove him.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-29)

Removal
-------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Removal")]

> [![Image 6: Avatar of Sam Altman](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Sam_Altman_TechCrunch_SF_2019_Day_2_Oct_3_%28cropped%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/40px-Sam_Altman_TechCrunch_SF_2019_Day_2_Oct_3_%28cropped%29_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Sam_Altman_TechCrunch_SF_2019_Day_2_Oct_3_(cropped)_(cropped).jpg "Avatar of Sam Altman")
> 
> Avatar of Sam Altman**Sam Altman**
> 
> @sama
> 
> 
> i loved my time at openai. it was transformative for me personally, and hopefully the world a little bit.
> 
> 
> 
> November 17, 2023[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-30)

On November 17, 2023, at approximately noon [PST](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Time "Pacific Time"),[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-EngadgetEvents-31) OpenAI's board of directors ousted Altman effective immediately following a "deliberative review process". The board concluded that Altman was not "consistently candid in his communications".[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-WaPoInfo-32) Altman was informed of his removal five to ten minutes before it occurred[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-33) on a [Google Meet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Meet "Google Meet")[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-34) while watching the [Las Vegas Grand Prix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Las_Vegas_Grand_Prix "Las Vegas Grand Prix").[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-35) Within thirty minutes,[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-36) Sutskever invited OpenAI chairman and president [Greg Brockman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Brockman "Greg Brockman") to a Google Meet to inform him of Altman's removal.[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-EngadgetEvents-31) According to an internal memo obtained by _Axios_, the removal was not due to "malfeasance",[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-37) and OpenAI chief executive [Emmett Shear](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emmett_Shear "Emmett Shear") denied accusations that the removal was due to disagreements.[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-38) The board publicly announced Altman's removal thirty minutes later.[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-39)

Chief Technology Officer [Mira Murati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mira_Murati "Mira Murati") was immediately appointed to interim chief executive officer. Hours after Altman's removal, Brockman resigned as chairman,[[40]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-40) joined by director of research [Jakub Pachocki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jakub_Pachocki "Jakub Pachocki") and researchers [Aleksander Mądry](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Aleksander_M%C4%85dry&action=edit&redlink=1 "Aleksander Mądry (page does not exist)")[[pl](https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksander_M%C4%85dry "pl:Aleksander Mądry")] and Szymon Sidor.[[41]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-41) During an all-hands meeting, Sutskever defended the ouster and denied accusations of a hostile takeover.[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-NYTimesRoose-12) An OpenAI representative requested former board member [Will Hurd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Will_Hurd "Will Hurd")'s presence.[[42]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-42)

Reinstatement
-------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Reinstatement")]

[Tiger Global Management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiger_Global_Management "Tiger Global Management") and Sequoia Capital had attempted to reinstate Altman, according to _[The Information](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Information\_(website) "The Information (website)")_;[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-43)[Bloomberg News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bloomberg_News "Bloomberg News") reported that Microsoft and [Thrive Capital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thrive_Capital "Thrive Capital") were seeking Altman's reinstatement.[[44]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-BloombergReinstatement-44) On November 18, _The Verge_ reported that OpenAI's board of directors discussed reinstating Altman. The board agreed in principle to resign and to allow Altman to return, but missed the deadline.[[45]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-45) According to _The Verge_, Altman was ambivalent about returning and would seek significant changes to the company,[[46]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-46) including replacing the board.[[47]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-47) A list of directors had been prepared by investors in the event that the board steps down, and purportedly included former [Salesforce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salesforce "Salesforce") executive [Bret Taylor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bret_Taylor "Bret Taylor").[[44]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-BloombergReinstatement-44) According to chief strategy officer Jason Kwon, OpenAI was optimistic it could return Altman, Brockman, and other employees.[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-48)

On November 19, Altman and Brockman appeared at OpenAI's headquarters to negotiate, mediated by Nadella. According to Bloomberg News, Murati, Kwon, and chief operating officer Brad Lightcap were pushing for a new board of directors; it was required that the board absolve him of wrongdoing in order for Altman to be reinstated. Taylor was expected be a member of the new board[[49]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-49) and Microsoft had also attempted to gain a seat.[[50]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-50)_[The Wall Street Journal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Wall\_Street\_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")_ reported that [Airbnb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airbnb "Airbnb") chief executive [Brian Chesky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Chesky "Brian Chesky") and businesswoman [Laurene Powell Jobs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laurene_Powell_Jobs "Laurene Powell Jobs") were also considered.[[51]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-WSJLeadership-51) Murati had intended to rehire Altman and Brockman, discussing the move with [Adam D'Angelo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adam_D%27Angelo "Adam D'Angelo").[[52]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-:0-52)_The Verge_ reported that Altman intended to return to OpenAI with support from Sutskever.[[53]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-53)

The board chose to name former [Twitch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitch_(service) "Twitch (service)") chief executive [Emmett Shear](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emmett_Shear "Emmett Shear") as OpenAI's chief executive[[54]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-54) instead of reinstating Altman.[[51]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-WSJLeadership-51) Former [GitHub](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GitHub "GitHub") chief executive [Nat Friedman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nat_Friedman "Nat Friedman") and Scale AI chief executive Alex Wang reportedly rejected executive offers from the board.[[55]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-55)[Anthropic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthropic "Anthropic") chief executive Dario Amodei[[56]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-56) refused to negotiate a deal that could have led to a merge of the two companies.[[57]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-57) In response, Microsoft appointed Altman as the chief executive of an artificial intelligence research team,[[58]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-:1-58) joined by Brockman, Pachocki, Sidor, and Madry.[[59]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-NYTimesExodus-59) Shear expressed interest in commercializing OpenAI with the board's support[[60]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-60) and stated his intentions to begin an investigation into Altman's removal.[[61]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-61)

Dozens of employees announced their resignations in response to Shear's accession.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-Efrati-4) The next day, a letter signed by 745[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-AxiosPossibilities-62) of OpenAI's 770 employees threatened mass resignations if the board does not resign; among the signatories was board member Sutskever, who defected from the board and publicly apologized for his participation in the board's previous actions.[[63]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-63) On November 21, _The Verge_ reported that Altman was reinstated with Taylor, D'Angelo, and economist [Lawrence Summers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawrence_Summers "Lawrence Summers") on an interim[[64]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-64) board.[[65]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-65) Taylor will chair the board.[[66]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-66) As part of the compromise deal, Altman and Brockman will not reclaim seats on the board. Altman agreed to an internal investigation into his alleged conduct,[[67]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-67) selecting two lawyers from [WilmerHale](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilmer_Cutler_Pickering_Hale_and_Dorr "Wilmer Cutler Pickering Hale and Dorr") to conduct the inquiry.[[68]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-68)

In March 2024, the investigation determined that Altman's behavior "did not mandate removal". Taylor announced that Altman would rejoin OpenAI's board of directors with former [Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_and_Melinda_Gates_Foundation "Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation") chief executive [Sue Desmond-Hellmann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sue_Desmond-Hellmann "Sue Desmond-Hellmann"), former [Sony Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony_Corporation "Sony Corporation") general counsel [Nicole Seligman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicole_Seligman "Nicole Seligman"), and [Instacart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instacart "Instacart") chief executive [Fidji Simo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fidji_Simo "Fidji Simo").[[69]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-69)

In May 2024, after [OpenAI's non-disparagement agreements](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI#Non-disparagement_agreement "OpenAI") were exposed, Altman was accused of lying when claiming to have been unaware of the equity cancellation provision for departing employees that don't sign the agreement.[[70]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-70) Also in May, former board member [Helen Toner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helen_Toner "Helen Toner") explained the board's rationale for firing Altman in November 2023. She stated that Altman had withheld information, for example about the release of ChatGPT and his ownership of OpenAI's startup fund. She said that Altman provided "inaccurate information about the small number of formal safety processes that the company did have in place". She also alleged that two executives in OpenAI had reported to the board "psychological abuse" from Altman, and provided screenshots and documentation of "lying and being manipulative in different situations". She said that many employees feared retaliation if they didn't support Altman, and that he had already been fired from Loopt because of what the management team had called "deceptive and chaotic behavior".[[71]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-71)[[72]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-72)

Aftermath
---------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Aftermath")]

### OpenAI

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: OpenAI")]

The removal left OpenAI in "chaos", according to _[The New York Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_New\_York\_Times "The New York Times")_.[[73]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-73) According to Bloomberg News, a significant number of OpenAI engineers threatened to resign if the board did not reconsider Altman's removal.[[74]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-BloombergInside-74)

According to _The Information_, Altman's removal risked a share sale led by Thrive Capital valuing the company at US$86 billion.[[75]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-75) A potential second tender offer for early-stage investors was also at risk.[[76]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-76)_The Information_ later reported that Thrive Capital's tender offer will continue after Altman's reinstatement.[[77]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-77)

OpenAI delayed the release of its online chatbot store as a result of Altman's removal.[[78]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-78)

### Market effects

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Market effects")]

Shares in Microsoft fell nearly three percent following the announcement.[[79]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-79) According to _[CoinDesk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CoinDesk "CoinDesk")_, the value of [Worldcoin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worldcoin "Worldcoin"), an iris biometric [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency "Cryptocurrency") co-founded by Altman, decreased twelve percent.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-SlateInfo-5) After hiring Altman, Microsoft's stock price rose over two percent to an all-time high.[[80]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-80)

Altman's removal benefited OpenAI's competitors, such as [Anthropic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthropic "Anthropic"), Quora, [Hugging Face](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hugging_Face "Hugging Face"), [Meta Platforms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meta_Platforms "Meta Platforms"), and [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google "Google").[[81]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-81)_[The Economist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Economist "The Economist")_ wrote that the removal could slow down the artificial intelligence industry as a whole.[[82]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-82)[Google DeepMind](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_DeepMind "Google DeepMind") received an increase in applicants, according to _The Information_; [Cohere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cohere "Cohere") and Adept engaged in an active effort to hire OpenAI employees.[[83]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-83) Several investors considered writing down their OpenAI investments to zero, impacting the company's ability to raise capital.[[74]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-BloombergInside-74) Over one hundred companies using OpenAI contacted Anthropic, according to _The Information_; others reached out to [Google Cloud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Cloud "Google Cloud"), Cohere, and [Microsoft Azure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Azure "Microsoft Azure").[[84]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-84)

### Potential venture

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Potential venture")]

According to _The Information_, Altman is planning a new artificial intelligence venture with Brockman,[[85]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-85) among other OpenAI employees.[[86]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-86)[Sequoia Capital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequoia_Capital "Sequoia Capital") investor [Alfred Lin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_Lin "Alfred Lin") and venture capitalist [Vinod Khosla](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vinod_Khosla "Vinod Khosla") expressed interest in Altman's potential venture.[[87]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-87)[[88]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-88)

### Legal action

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Legal action")]

Multiple OpenAI investors are considering legal action.[[89]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-89) On December 8, the [Competition and Markets Authority](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_and_Markets_Authority "Competition and Markets Authority") announced it was beginning a preliminary investigation into Microsoft's relationship with OpenAI and its non-voting board observership.[[90]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-90) Hours later, Bloomberg News reported that the [Federal Trade Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Trade_Commission "Federal Trade Commission") was separately examining the relationship.[[91]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-91) In response, Microsoft stated that it does not hold a stake in OpenAI.[[92]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-92)

In February 2024, the [U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Securities_and_Exchange_Commission "U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission") was reportedly investigating OpenAI over whether internal company communications made by Altman were used to mislead investors, while an investigation of Altman's statements that was opened by the [Southern New York U.S. Attorney's Office](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Attorney_for_the_Southern_District_of_New_York "United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York") opened the previous November was ongoing.[[93]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-93)[[94]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-94)

Reactions
---------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Reactions")]

### Sam Altman

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Sam Altman")]

Altman quipped that the OpenAI board of directors should sue him should he "start going off".[[95]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-95) Former co-chair [Elon Musk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elon_Musk "Elon Musk") stated the board should be transparent in its removal.[[96]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-96) At the 2023 DealBook Summit, Musk called the turmoil "troubling" and that he had "mixed feelings" towards Altman.[[97]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-97) Allies of Altman accused board members of staging a coup[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-NYTimesRoose-12) and several OpenAI employees responded to a tweet Altman wrote with a heart emoji, intended to demonstrate employees who are prepared to leave.[[98]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-98) Former Google chief executive [Eric Schmidt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eric_Schmidt "Eric Schmidt") wrote that Altman was a "hero to [him]" after his removal.[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-WaPoInfo-32)

### Technology industry

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Technology industry")]

Microsoft executives were informed of Altman's removal a minute before the announcement was made, according to _Axios_,[[99]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-99) and investors were not given advance knowledge. Satya Nadella and chief technology officer [Kevin Scott](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Scott_(computer_scientist) "Kevin Scott (computer scientist)") expressed confidence in OpenAI following his removal,[[100]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-100) though Nadella was reportedly furious, according to Bloomberg News.[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-BloombergCoup-24)

[Y Combinator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Y_Combinator "Y Combinator") co-founder [Paul Graham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Graham_(programmer) "Paul Graham (programmer)") referred to the board's members as "misbehaving children".[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-AxiosBackground-27)[Third Point](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third_Point "Third Point") chief executive and Microsoft shareholder [Daniel S. Loeb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_S._Loeb "Daniel S. Loeb") stated that OpenAI had "stunningly poor governance".[[101]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-101) French digital transition minister [Jean-Noël Barrot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-No%C3%ABl_Barrot "Jean-Noël Barrot") stated that Altman is "welcome in France".[[102]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-102)

Following the employee letter, Salesforce chief executive [Marc Benioff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc_Benioff "Marc Benioff") offered to employ OpenAI employees with matching salaries,[[103]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-103) an offer extended by Microsoft.[[104]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-104)

### Media analysis

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Media analysis")]

_[Wired](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wired\_(magazine) "Wired (magazine)")_ editor-at-large [Steven Levy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steven_Levy "Steven Levy") compared the removal of Altman to the removal of [Steve Jobs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Jobs "Steve Jobs") from [Apple](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple,_Inc. "Apple, Inc.") in 1985,[[105]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-105) a comparison made by _The New York Times_.[[106]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-106)_Axios_ posed that the board could resign, returning OpenAI to Altman.[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-AxiosPossibilities-62) Writing for _The New York Times_, [Ezra Klein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ezra_Klein "Ezra Klein") noted the role of OpenAI's controlling non-profit in self-regulation.[[107]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-107) Analyst Fred Havemeyer stated that Nadella "pulled off a coup of his own" in hiring Altman in _[The Washington Post](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Washington\_Post "The Washington Post")_.[[108]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-108) Altman was named as _[Time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time\_(magazine) "Time (magazine)")_'s CEO of the Year for 2023, owing partially to his removal.[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-109)

### Other

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Other")]

In October 2024, [Nobel Prize](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nobel_Prize "Nobel Prize") winner [Geoffrey Hinton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geoffrey_Hinton "Geoffrey Hinton") declared that he was proud that [Ilya Sutskever](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ilya_Sutskever "Ilya Sutskever"), a former student of his, was responsible for firing Altman.[[110]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI#cite_note-110)

# Why California’s attorney general must continue the investigation into OpenAI

by Orson Aguilar and Catherine Bracy

[Republish](https://calmatters.org/about/republish/)

### Share this:

* [Click to share on X (Opens in new window)
  X](https://calmatters.org/commentary/2025/07/california-attorney-general-openai-investigation/?share=x&nb=1)
* [Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  Facebook](https://calmatters.org/commentary/2025/07/california-attorney-general-openai-investigation/?share=facebook&nb=1)
* [Click to share on WhatsApp (Opens in new window)
  WhatsApp](https://calmatters.org/commentary/2025/07/california-attorney-general-openai-investigation/?share=jetpack-whatsapp&nb=1)



Guest Commentary written by

### Orson Aguilar

Orson Aguilar is the founding president and CEO of LatinoProsperity. A Boyles Height, Los Angeles, native, he is a board member of The East Los Angeles Community Corporation and Innovate Public Schools.

### Catherine Bracy

Catherine Bracy is the founder and CEO of TechEquity. She is the author of “[World Eaters](https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/723091/world-eaters-by-catherine-bracy/),” and previously served as Code for America’s senior director of partnerships and ecosystem.

Just days after [abandoning its planned conversion](https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/business/story/2025-05-05/openai-says-its-non-profit-will-remain-in-control-of-its-for-profit-business) to a for-profit entity and proclaiming it would remain a nonprofit, OpenAI puzzled us with another announcement: a nearly [$6.5 billion deal to buy io](https://www.npr.org/2025/05/22/nx-s1-5407548/openai-jony-ive-io-deal-ai-devices), a start-up created by former Apple executive and iPhone designer Jony Ive.

This isn’t the only business deal OpenAI has in the works. The company also [announced plans](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/05/22/technology/openai-uae-data-centers.html) to build a massive new data center in the United Arab Emirates and has [reportedly purchased](https://www.reuters.com/business/openai-agrees-buy-windsurf-about-3-billion-bloomberg-news-reports-2025-05-06/) AI startup Windsurf.

If anyone was under the impression that OpenAI’s decision to remain a nonprofit is a win for the public, its profit-driven business moves should put that to rest. Deals like these, which require OpenAI to sell stakes in the company, erode the nonprofit’s control of the business.

Meanwhile, OpenAI has still not answered fundamental questions about how their conversion to a public benefit corporation will maintain the nonprofit’s independent oversight. Which of OpenAI’s entities owns the technologies it develops? How will OpenAI avoid conflicts of interest and self-dealing among executives and investors? Who will reap the funds that the for-profit sows? Most of all, what happens when shareholder interests conflict with the public interest that the nonprofit is legally bound to serve?

Without answers to these critical questions, the [investigations into OpenAI’s structure](https://calmatters.org/economy/technology/2025/01/openai-investigation-california/) by the California and Delaware attorneys general must continue.

OpenAI was originally founded as a nonprofit to ensure artificial intelligence would benefit all of humanity. Today, it is operating under a structure that allows profit and commercial gain to take priority over its mission to serve the public good.

Since 2019, OpenAI has methodically shifted power away from its nonprofit parent organization into a tangled web of [business deals and investor relationships](https://www.reuters.com/technology/artificial-intelligence/openai-raise-40-billion-softbank-led-new-funding-2025-03-31/). Meanwhile, the nonprofit increasingly plays the role of a weak and passive bystander rather than a steward of the public interest — its assets are largely unaccounted for and its ability to steer AI toward meaningful public benefits is deeply compromised.

OpenAI’s latest pivot is a clever rebranding of its problematic business-as-usual approach. It’s a way to deflect lawsuits, avoid further scrutiny and put the interests of investors ahead of the everyday people OpenAI is legally required to serve.

## Read Next

[Technology](https://calmatters.org/category/economy/technology/)

### [California is investigating OpenAI’s conversion to a for-profit company](https://calmatters.org/economy/technology/2025/01/openai-investigation-california/)

by [Khari Johnson](https://calmatters.org/author/khari-johnson/)

The public deserves answers and transparency. While disputes over governance structures and the legalities of nonprofit ownership may seem tedious and disconnected from the lives of everyday people, OpenAI’s future has huge implications for the well-being of society.

On the one hand, artificial intelligence is leading to breakthroughs that are helping us [adapt to climate change](https://www.forbes.com/sites/heatherwishartsmith/2025/04/01/how-ai-is-transforming-climate-change-prediction-and-mitigation/), [detect deadly diseases](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41591-025-03714-7) and simply give us more time back in our busy lives. On the opposite end, the technology is also [accelerating greenhouse gas emissions](https://www.axios.com/2025/04/22/ai-climate-toll-imf-study), while leading to [wrongful incarceration](https://innocenceproject.org/news/artificial-intelligence-is-putting-innocent-people-at-risk-of-being-incarcerated/), [unemployment](https://www.wsj.com/articles/it-unemployment-rises-to-5-7-as-ai-hits-tech-jobs-7726bb1b) and [worldwide misinformation](https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/ai-image-misinformation-surged-google-research-finds-rcna154333).

In OpenAI’s own [founding words](https://openai.com/index/introducing-openai/): “It’s hard to fathom how much human-level AI could benefit society, and it’s equally hard to imagine how much it could damage society if built or used incorrectly.” If OpenAI’s charitable assets were separated from its commercial interests and put into the hands of a fully independent nonprofit that can carry out its original mission, there is a much better chance of ensuring the positive future vision for AI than the negative.

That’s why the attorneys general of California and Delaware need to take decisive action in their ongoing [investigations into OpenAI’s restructuring](https://apnews.com/article/openai-chatgpt-nonprofit-aad1fddb75a19008a1a349d1c972d476). There must be robust investigation and oversight of OpenAI’s governance structure, including a review of past compliance with California charitable law. All nonprofit assets unrelated to governance should be fairly valued and required to transfer to a new, fully independent charitable entity dedicated to maximizing public benefit. Lastly, the nonprofit board needs true independence and ongoing oversight power to hold OpenAI accountable.

OpenAI started as a nonprofit, which means it must serve the public good, not private interests. Yet for years, OpenAI has been using those charitable assets for commercial purposes, violating its mission. There must be a clear separation. That’s what OpenAI promised when it started, and it’s what the public deserves.

(Notably, the U.S. FTC opened an investigation into OpenAI back in 2023 over privacy and misinformation harms foley.com, and that scrutiny remains ongoing.) Altman’s transparency here – effectively saying _“we could release this now, but it might be risky so we won’t yet”_ – marks a maturation in OpenAI’s approach compared to earlier, more aggressive launches. [...] creative community. In late 2024, protesters leaked an early Sora model and some artists in the beta program penned an open letter accusing OpenAI of _“exploiting unpaid labour”_ and lacking transparency with those testers techfundingnews.com. _“Dear corporate AI overlords,”_ the frustrated letter began, highlighting tensions between tech companies and artists concerned about being marginalized by AI techfundingnews.com. OpenAI responded by emphasizing the safeguards against misuse built into [...] As we head into the latter half of 2025, all eyes are on OpenAI – and indeed the whole industry – to see whether these developments truly _change the game_ for the better. _“The future of AI just got a lot closer,”_ one expert remarked, _“and OpenAI is both driving it and trying to hold it accountable at the same time.”_ With tech giants, startups, regulators, and society watching closely, one thing is clear: what OpenAI did in July 2025 has forever changed the trajectory of generative AI – and
